subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] new course for MemRise; new decks for ANKI
msgSnippet: To the fellow who created KingKong, Thank you very much.  I have tried to install KingKong, but it seems not to like Windows 7.  Is it available as a .ttf? I
messageBody:
To the fellow who created KingKong,

Thank you very much.  I have tried to install KingKong, but it seems not to like Windows 7.  Is it available as a .ttf?

I completely agree with you regarding your redesign of the keyboard.  I wish like heck it was like that!  I type a lot and I could be persuaded to try a totally new remapping.

There is one thing that I would like discussed, by whoever wishes to:  I do like most everything that I've read or experienced with Elmsworth's Suave font.  

--His suggestions here appear to deal with some of the ID problems that we have with regular QuickScript.  

--His "little dot" and his accent mark seem pretty unobtrusive.

--he does sacrifice a number of ligatures keys that--you're right--don't really add much to the typing experience.

--I do very much like that he has a number of hot keys that present one stroke for such frequent syllables as "-tion".  
He does also sacrifice the x's and the half letters.  Aesthetically, I'm not totally for that.  However, I want to believe that the lack of these would not greatly hindering the reader on texts that do use them.

Ben





On Monday, September 28, 2015 4:15 AM, "Nathan Sharfi mailinglists@... [Read_Alphabet]" <Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com> wrote:


 
Neat!

A few things:

- you may want to explicitly note what keyboard layout you're using. I made King Kong (<https://github.com/adiabatic/king-kong>), and to type "Charlotte" I'd press "H5d;jl" (without quotes).

- What's an ingle? (<http://www.memrise.com/course/784058/quickscript-for-beginners/5/>)

- I have trouble recognizing ŋ in the middle of a word, too; I usually end up having to check with a dictionary. I use <http://www.macmillandictionary.com/us/dictionary/british/off_1> at the bottom there's a link to <http://www.macmillandictionary.com/us/options.html> where you can change your default to British English. This won't correct for happy-tensing (<http://phonetic-blog.blogspot.com/2012/06/happy-again.html>), though.

- I never did catch the difference between "et roe" and "eight roe" — and I can't easily tell them apart (SoCal native here). Read seems to prefer "eight roe" for everything in the SQUARE lexical set, but I'm way out of my league here. Can someone fire up the Cowan-signal?

- The font and materials you're learning from seem to have some lingering Shavianisms — <http://www.memrise.com/course/784058/quickscript-for-beginners/8/> reifies "yew", "ian", "ear", "air", "ark", "orb" and "er". While Read explicitly notes [ju] and [ɛər] on the second page of the manual, he didn't bother giving them special names, just as we've never bothered giving special names to ligatures like ffl and fi.


On Sep 26, 2015, at 9:45 AM, trybloganatgmail@... [Read_Alphabet] <Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com> wrote:


Hello to all,

Now I've gotten the QuickScript bug!

I figure my best contribution is to upload a MemRise course on the subject <http://www.memrise.com/course/784058/quickscript-for-beginners/>, and--while I'm at it--make some ANKI decks.

Fun, fun, fun!  I do not know what to do about reconciling Read's English with my own South-Eastern US accent.  For now, I'm tending toward Read's methods, though I often don't agree with his vowels.  And I cannot bring myself to "garage" with a soft "zh".  Other than that, things will sift out.

I welcome your comments, and thank you so much for this site!

Sincerely,

Ben

</div><div dir=3D"ltr" id=3D"yui_3_16_0_1_1443468736898_4239">--he does sac=
rifice a number of ligatures keys that--you're right--don't really add much=
 to the typing experience.</div><div dir=3D"ltr" id=3D"yui_3_16_0_1_1443468=
736898_4239"><br></div><div dir=3D"ltr" id=3D"yui_3_16_0_1_1443468736898_42=
39">--I do very much like that he has a number of hot keys that present one=
 stroke for such frequent syllables as "-tion".  </div><div dir=3D"ltr=
" id=3D"yui_3_16_0_1_1443468736898_4239">He does also sacrifice the x's and=
 the half letters.  Aesthetically, I'm not totally for that.  How=
ever, I want to believe that the lack of these would not greatly hindering =
the reader on texts that do use them.</div><div dir=3D"ltr" id=3D"yui_3_16_=
0_1_1443468736898_4239"><br></div><div dir=3D"ltr" id=3D"yui_3_16_0_1_14434=
68736898_4239">Ben</div><div dir=3D"ltr" id=3D"yui_3_16_0_1_1443468736898_4=
307"><br></div><div dir=3D"ltr" id=3D"yui_3_16_0_1_1443468736898_5316"><br>=

      <div>Neat!</div><div class=3D"yiv2120245441class"><br clear=
=3D"none" class=3D"yiv2120245441class"></div><div class=3D"yiv2120245441cla=
ss">A few things:</div><div class=3D"yiv2120245441class"><br clear=3D"none"=
 class=3D"yiv2120245441class"></div><div class=3D"yiv2120245441class">- you=
 may want to explicitly note what keyboard layout you're using. I made King=
 Kong (<<a rel=3D"nofollow" shape=3D"rect" class=3D"yiv2120245441class" =
target=3D"_blank" href=3D"https://github.com/adiabatic/king-kong">https://g=
ithub.com/adiabatic/king-kong</a>>), and to type "Charlotte" I'd press "=
H5d;jl" (without quotes).</div><div class=3D"yiv2120245441class"><br clear=
=3D"none" class=3D"yiv2120245441class"></div><div class=3D"yiv2120245441cla=
ss">- What's an ingle? (<<a rel=3D"nofollow" shape=3D"rect" class=3D"yiv=
2120245441class" target=3D"_blank" href=3D"http://www.memrise.com/course/78=
4058/quickscript-for-beginners/5/">http://www.memrise.com/course/784058/qui=
ckscript-for-beginners/5/</a>>)</div><div class=3D"yiv2120245441class"><=
br clear=3D"none" class=3D"yiv2120245441class"></div><div class=3D"yiv21202=
45441class">- I have trouble recognizing =C5=8B in the middle of a word, to=
o; I usually end up having to check with a dictionary. I use <<a rel=3D"=
nofollow" shape=3D"rect" class=3D"yiv2120245441class" target=3D"_blank" hre=
f=3D"http://www.macmillandictionary.com/us/dictionary/british/off_1">http:/=
/www.macmillandictionary.com/us/dictionary/british/off_1</a>> at the bot=
tom there's a link to <<a rel=3D"nofollow" shape=3D"rect" class=3D"yiv21=
20245441class" target=3D"_blank" href=3D"http://www.macmillandictionary.com=
/us/options.html">http://www.macmillandictionary.com/us/options.html</a>&gt=
; where you can change your default to British English. This won't correct =
for happy-tensing (<<a rel=3D"nofollow" shape=3D"rect" class=3D"yiv21202=
45441class" target=3D"_blank" href=3D"http://phonetic-blog.blogspot.com/201=
2/06/happy-again.html">http://phonetic-blog.blogspot.com/2012/06/happy-agai=
n.html</a>>), though.</div><div class=3D"yiv2120245441class"><br clear=
=3D"none" class=3D"yiv2120245441class"></div><div class=3D"yiv2120245441cla=
ss">- I never did catch the difference between "et roe" and "eight roe" =E2=
=80=94 and I can't easily tell them apart (SoCal native here). Read seems t=
o prefer "eight roe" for everything in the SQUARE lexical set, but I'm way =
out of my league here. Can someone fire up the Cowan-signal?</div><div clas=
s=3D"yiv2120245441class"><br clear=3D"none" class=3D"yiv2120245441class"></=
div><div class=3D"yiv2120245441class">- The font and materials you're learn=
ing from seem to have some lingering Shavianisms =E2=80=94 <<a rel=3D"no=
follow" shape=3D"rect" class=3D"yiv2120245441class" target=3D"_blank" href=
=3D"http://www.memrise.com/course/784058/quickscript-for-beginners/8/">http=
://www.memrise.com/course/784058/quickscript-for-beginners/8/</a>> reifi=
es "yew", "ian", "ear", "air", "ark", "orb" and "er". While Read explicitly=
 notes [ju] and [=C9=9B=C9=99r] on the second page of the manual, he didn't=
 bother giving them special names, just as we've never bothered giving spec=
ial names to ligatures like ffl and fi.</div><div class=3D"yiv2120245441cla=
ss"><br clear=3D"none" class=3D"yiv2120245441class"></div><div class=3D"yiv=
